questions.text: The following image shows the chest X-ray of a preterm neonate who was admitted to the NICU in view of severe respiratory distress.  What does this suggest?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture of respiratory distress in a premature neonate and the X-ray findings of diffuse ground-glass (reticulo-granular) opacities with a characteristic white-out appearance, hyaline membrane disease (HMD) is the most likely diagnosis.

HMD, also known as neonatal Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is a relatively common condition resulting from insufficient production of surfactant that occurs in preterm neonates. Maternal diabetes, perinatal asphyxia, and multiple gestations are other known risk factors for the condition. Clinical features include tachypnea, chest retractions, expiratory grunting, and nasal flaring. The infant may or may not be cyanosed. 

X-ray features of HMD include:

  • Air bronchogram sign
  • Diffuse ground-glass opacities
  • Obliteration of cardiac and diaphragmatic contours giving rise to 'white-out' lung (indicates severe disease)

 

Chest radiograph (A) shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important risk factor for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome?
questions.solution:
Respiratory distress syndrome occurs primarily in premature infants. Its incidence is inversely related to gestational age and birthweight. It occurs in 60–80% of infants delivered at <28 wk of gestational age, in 15–30% of those delivered between 32 and 36 weeks of gestational age, and rarely in those delivered at >37 wk of gestational age.

Other risk factors include the following:

  • Maternal diabetes
  • Multiple births
  • Cesarean delivery
  • Asphyxia
  • History of previously affected siblings

questions.text: A father runs to a PHC with a baby wrapped in a towel. The neonate was delivered a few hours back, at home, by the local dai. On initial examination, the medical officer notes cyanosis and severe tachypnoea. Which of the following features would favor a diagnosis of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome in this child?

choices.text: Patchy coarse infiltrates on chest X-ray
Emaciated appearance with palmar and plantar creases
Onset of distress after 6 hours of birth

questions.solution:
Air bronchogram on chest x-ray is suggestive of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

Other chest x-ray findings in respiratory distress syndrome (RDS):

  • Fine reticulogranular pattern
  • Bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Option A: Patchy coarse infiltrates are associated with meconium aspiration syndrome.

Option C: Reduced fat under the skin resulting in an emaciated appearance as well as prominent creases is a feature of post-term babies. Respiratory distress syndrome is more common among preterm babies 

Option D: Onset of respiratory distress syndrome is within 6 hours of birth. 

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the treatment of RDS with surfactant is false?

choices.text: It is given in neonates with RDS who fail CPAP
It is given prophylactically to all neonates at < 31 weeks gestation.
It can be given as rescue treatment when RDS actually develops.
Repeated dosing is given every 6-12 hr for a total of 2 to 4 doses.

questions.solution:
Surfactant is given prophylactically to all neonates < 28 weeks, not 31 weeks. It is given irrespective of the presence or absence of RDS. The route of administration is intratracheal.

Surfactant is indicated in all infants with moderate to severe RDS. It is also given as a rescue treatment when CPAP fails.

questions.text: A first-year resident receives a call from the casualty regarding an unbooked primigravida, at 32 weeks of gestation. She has presented with regular painful uterine contractions. On examination, her cervix is 2cm dilated. What dose of betamethasone injection should the resident give her?
questions.solution:
The woman is currently in preterm labour and the dose of antenatal betamethasone given for avoiding complications of prematurity is 12mg IM every 24 hours (total 2 doses).

Dexamethasone is used, the dose is 6mg IM every 12 hours (total 4 doses).

Corticosteroid administration is recommended for all women in preterm labour (<34 weeks of gestation).

Antenatal steroid administration reduces the risk of the following: (RINN)

  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)
  • Intraventricular haemorrhage (IVH)
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC)
  • Neurodevelopmental delay

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of recurrent late-trimester abortions is in preterm labor, presumed to be due to chorioamnionitis. She has received one dose of betamethasone injection. This is a precious pregnancy and the relatives are concerned about prematurity-related complications in the baby. Which of the following is useful for assessing lung maturity in this fetus?
questions.solution:
The lecithin–sphingomyelin ratio (L/S ratio) is an amniotic fluid test used to assess fetal lung maturity. L/S ratio of < 2 in amniotic fluid indicates lung immaturity. 

Surfactant starts appearing in the fetal lung by 20 weeks of gestation. Levels indicating lung maturity are detected after 35 weeks.

Surfactant is a complex mixture of lipids, proteins, and carbohydrates produced by type II pneumocytes in the lung epithelium. The absence of surfactant in the liquid film lining the alveoli causes an increase in surface tension and alveolar collapse. If not treated, such atelectasis leads to increased work of breathing, intrapulmonary shunting, ventilation-perfusion mismatch, hypoxia, and eventually respiratory failure. 

The relative concentration of the phospholipids lecithin (L) and sphingomyelin (S) is an indicator of lung maturity. The outward flow of pulmonary secretions from the fetal lungs into the amniotic fluid maintains the level of lecithin and sphingomyelin equally until 32–33 weeks gestation when the lecithin concentration begins to increase significantly while sphingomyelin remains nearly the same. An L–S ratio of 2.5 or more indicates fetal lung maturity while an L/S ratio of less than 1.5 is associated with a high risk of infant respiratory distress syndrome.

Other tests done to assess fetal lung maturity are:

  • Shake test/bubble test
  • Phosphatidyl glycerol measurement
  • Surfactant:albumin ratio
  • Lamellar body counts

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of fetal lung maturity?

choices.text: Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

questions.solution:
Nile blue test showing >50% orange cells is a sign of fetal lung maturity, not blue cells.

Tests for the assessment of fetal lung maturity include: 

The Nile blue test involves staining desquamated fetal cells from amniotic fluid with 0.1% Nile blue sulfate. The presence of orange cells > 50% suggests lung maturity. Lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio at 31 to 32 weeks is 1, and at 35 weeks ratio is 2. The ratio ≥2 indicates lung maturity (option A). 

The shake test or bubble test (Clement's test) (option B) involves mixing amniotic fluid with 95% ethanol, shaking it for 15 seconds, and observing it for 15 minutes. A complete ring of bubbles at the meniscus is a positive test and indicates lung maturity. This is a useful bedside test.

The presence of phosphatidylglycerol, (option C) saturated phosphatidylcholine and lamellar body count (>50,000/mcL) indicates lung maturity.

Glucocorticoids accelerate lung maturation and lower the incidence of respiratory distress and neonatal mortality in preterms if the birth was delayed for at least 24 hours after initiation of betamethasone. A single course of corticosteroids is recommended for women between 24 and 36 weeks who are at risk of delivery within 7 days. Intramuscular injections of either 2 doses of 12 mg betamethasone are given 24 hourly or 4 doses of 6 mg dexamethasone are given 12 hourly.

questions.text: A female infant was born in a community hospital by spontaneous vaginal delivery at 34 weeks of gestation. 30 minutes later, the baby’s breathing became excessively laboured. Despite providing non-invasive ventilation, the baby died. Post-mortem histopathological examination of the lung showed thick pink membranes lining the small, collapsed alveolar spaces and necrotic debris, mainly within the respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and unopened alveoli. What are these membranes chiefly composed of?
questions.solution:
The history of respiratory distress in a premature baby (34 weeks) and a biopsy showing pink (hyaline) membranes in the alveoli is indicative of hyaline membrane disease (HMD). The hyaline membranes are composed of layers of fibrin-rich edema fluid and necrotic cells of lining alveoli. Diffuse ischemic damage to the alveoli causes the transudation of proteins into the alveoli to form the hyaline membrane.

Hyaline membrane disease (HMD), also known as infantile respiratory distress syndrome (IRDS) or respiratory distress syndrome of newborns (RDS) is a syndrome in premature infants caused by developmental insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant production and structural immaturity of the lungs.

questions.text: A primigravida was taken up for emergency cesarean section in view of placental abruption, at 32 weeks of gestation. Immediately after delivery, you dry the baby, clear secretions from the mouth and nose, and provide tactile stimulation. But even after 30 seconds, you note the baby is still gasping for breath and oxygen saturation has not increased more than 92%. Which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of respiratory distress in a preterm infant is neonatal RDS (hyaline membrane disease). The infant has presented with moderate respiratory distress without any signs of respiratory failure so early continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is the appropriate treatment.

CPAP started at birth is the choice for the management of a preterm infant at risk for respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Early nasal CPAP has shown to lower mortality and risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia. Room air is better than oxygen for the resuscitation of preterm infants, and 100% oxygen is also harmful, causing increased oxidative stress.

The intubate-surfactant-extubate (INSURE) on CPAP technique is recommended for surfactant administration when babies showed signs of RDS and needed more than 30% inspired oxygen to maintain saturation in the normal range.

questions.text: A 3-hour-old neonate with apnea has been on bag and mask ventilation for the last 30 seconds. She has now started taking spontaneous breaths. The heart rate is still between 100 and 110/min. What is your next step?
questions.solution:
As per the NRP algorithm, at any time during resuscitation, if the HR > 100 and spontaneous breathing resumes then discontinue ventilation.
The components of NRP resuscitation include: (TABCD)

  • Temperature- maintain between 36.5 and 37.5 C
  • Airway- "sniffing" position, clear secretions if needed
  • Breathing- free flow O2 (maintain sats 91–95%), PPV (40–60 breaths /min), ETT
  • Circulation- chest compressions:ventilation ratio (3:1 = 90:30; lower 1/3rd sternum; two thumb technique preferred)
  • Drugs- Epinephrine, volume expanders 

Algorithm states:

  • HR < 100/min + no respirations →  Positive pressure ventilation (PPV)
  • No response with PPV → Endotracheal intubation (ET)
  • HR < 60/min → Chest compressions
  • No response to chest compressions → epinephrine

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt. What would be the Silverman Anderson score?
questions.solution:
The Silverman-Anderson score of the child would be 8.

Calculation of the Silverman-Anderson score of this child: 

Criteria Finding Score
Expiratory grunt Audible with the naked ear 2
Nasal flaring Marked 2
Xiphoid retraction Marked 2
Intercostal retraction (lower chest) Minimal 1
Chest movement (upper chest) Lag  1

 Total score: 8

A score of more than 7 indicates respiratory failure.

The Silverman-Anderson score is a commonly used score to assess respiratory distress. It helps to assess the progression of distress over time and initiate treatment. It is more suited for preterms with respiratory distress syndrome. Scoring is to be done every half an hour and charting is carried out to monitor progress. 

The image below shows Silverman Anderson retraction score: 

Downes’ Score is also used for assessing the severity of respiratory distress. It is more comprehensive and can be applied to any gestational age and condition. Downe’s score of >7 means impending respiratory failure.

Score 0 1 2
Respiratory rate <60/min 60–80/min >80/min
Air entry Normal Mild decrease Marked decrease
Cyanosis Nil In-room air On >40% O2
Grunting None Only on auscultation Audible with the naked ear
Retraction Nil Mild Moderate

questions.text: As part of calculating Downe's score for a baby, you would assess all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Downe's score does not consider nasal flaring.

The severity of respiratory distress is assessed by Downe’s score and Silverman–Anderson score. Downe’s score can be applied for any gestational age. Downe’s score of >7 means impending respiratory failure. Silverman–Anderson score is more suited for preterms with hyaline membrane disease (HMD).

Downe's scoring

Score  0  1  2
Respiratory rate <60/min  60–80/min >80/min
Air entry  Normal Mild decrease Marked decrease
Cyanosis  Nil In room air On >40% O2
Grunting  None Only on auscultation Audible with naked ear
Retraction  Nil Mild Moderate

questions.text: Your brother-in-law calls you during one of your night duties and tells you that your sister just delivered a baby girl and that both the mother and the child are doing well following the cesarean delivery. The next morning, however, you get a call that the baby started having trouble breathing and has been shifted to the NICU. He also sends you a photo of her chest X-ray via WhatsApp. On the radiograph, you note streaky, perihilar linear densities and fluid in the horizontal fissure. Which of the following is true regarding the given clinical condition?

choices.text: Only observation and supportive therapy is needed
It can predispose to bronchopulmonary dysplasia

questions.solution:
Benign respiratory distress in a newborn with a chest X-ray showing fluid in the interlobar fissure is indicative of transient tachypnoea of newborn (TTN), also known as retained fetal lung liquid syndrome. The management of TTN is supportive oxygen therapy and observation. 

It is more common after a term, cesarean delivery and is due to the delayed clearance of the lung fluid from the interstitium into the pulmonary lymphatics.

Other findings of chest x-ray imaging are prominent (perihilar) pulmonary vascular markings, increased interstitial markings, and a “wet silhouette” around the heart. 

 

Chest radiograph (A) on day 1 at 6 hours shows a bilateral diffuse ground-glass appearance and fine granularity due to interstitial opacities.

Chest radiograph (B) of the same patient at the age of 2 days (B) shows that the pulmonary parenchymal opacities have decreased, though perihilar streaky markings are still present.

Treatment is supportive and minimal oxygen treatment (< 40%) is often adequate; infants usually recover within 3 days.

questions.text: A preterm, extremely low birth weight baby, delivered by emergency caesarian section was admitted to the NICU and treated for respiratory distress syndrome. She responded to treatment and was discharged. At 6 months of age, she is still having recurrent respiratory distress and requires supplemental oxygen at home. The baby was diagnosed with bronchopulmonary dysplasia. Which of the following does not cause this clinical complication?
questions.solution:
Inhalation of nitrous oxide (N2O) is not associated with bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD). Inhaled NO is a pulmonary vasodilator approved for the treatment of hypoxic respiratory failure in term and near-term infants with pulmonary hypertension. It may have a role in preventing BPD.

BPD is a pathologic process leading to clinical features of chronic lung disease that originates in the neonatal period and is defined by an oxygen requirement for 28 days postnatally. Inflammatory injury to the developing lungs due to barotrauma and oxygen toxicity resulting from prolonged mechanical ventilation is the key factor driving the pathogenesis of BPD. Together with other antenatal and postnatal factors, it results in aberrant tissue repair, dysregulated vascular and arrested alveolar development, which is the basis of the pathology seen in BPD.

questions.text: A female newborn was delivered at 40 weeks of gestation by emergency C-section, following signs of severe fetal distress. Greenish amniotic fluid was noted. Immediately following delivery, the baby was shifted to the NICU and had to be intubated. Her chest X-Ray is as below. What does it show?
questions.solution:
The image shows patchy infiltrates and coarse streaking, which are characteristic findings in the chest X-ray image of infants with meconium aspiration syndrome.

questions.text: A newborn infant,  delivered at home, at 42 weeks of gestation, became cyanotic and started breathing rapidly. The child was immediately taken to the nearby primary health centre. As the medical officer prepares to intubate, she notes greenish staining on the vocal cords. Which of the following is this baby likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Respiratory distress in a post-term neonate with a history of greenish (meconium-stained) amniotic fluid during delivery is suggestive of meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS). The aspirated meconium can block the large and small airways, causing patchy atelectasis and emphysema. This produces a ventilation-perfusion mismatch. Severe overinflation can lead to air leak syndromes such as pneumothorax. 

Meconium consists of water, desquamated GIT cells, skin, lanugo hair, vernix, bile salts, pancreatic enzymes, lipids, and mucopolysaccharides. The bile salts and pancreatic enzymes can cause chemical pneumonitis. Meconium can also cause surfactant inactivation by displacing it from the alveolar surface and inhibiting its surface tension-lowering ability. Severe MAS is associated with remodelling and thickening of the muscular walls, resulting in pulmonary hypertension. 

Infants who develop MAS typically present in the first 12 hours after birth with varying degrees of respiratory distress. On inspection, many affected infants have 'barrel chests'; crackles (rales) and rhonchi often can be heard on auscultation. In severe cases, the entire lungs can be involved resulting in a total “whiteout” of the lungs on the radiograph.

Listeriosis is an infection that is acquired from the mother and is reported to be rarely associated with meconium-stained amniotic fluid.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about apnea of prematurity (AOP)?

choices.text: Usually resolves by 37 weeks post conceptional age
Gentle tactile stimulation is often adequate for mild to moderate episodes
Recurrent AOP can be treated with caffeine or theophylline
AOP is a risk factor for Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)

questions.solution:
Apnea of prematurity (AOP) is not a risk factor for sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).

It is defined as cessation of breathing for longer than 20 seconds or for any duration if accompanied by cyanosis or bradycardia. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. It is seen in preterm infants and usually resolves by the 37th week of gestation. Recurrent apnea of prematurity may be treated with caffeine or theophylline. It does not predict the future occurrence of SIDS.

Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) is the sudden death of an infant under one year of age, which remains unexplained after a thorough case investigation, including the performance of a complete autopsy, examination of the death scene, and review of the clinical history.

questions.text: While monitoring the respiratory rate of the infants in the NICU, you notice one baby which suddenly stops breathing. Which of the following statements is true in this regard?

choices.text: Primary apnea is characterized by  labile BP and tachycardia
Caffeine therapy should be given in primary apnea
Secondary apnea responds to stimulation by establishing normal breathing.
Central asphyxia can cause secondary apnea

questions.solution:
Secondary apnea can occur as a central CNS meditated asphyxia or due to neuromuscular disorders. 

Apnea is the cessation of breathing for >20 seconds or for any duration if accompanied by bradycardia and cyanosis. 

Primary Apnea  Secondary Apnea
Failure to initiate respiratory effort at birth Apnea developing in an infant who has initiated a respiratory effort
There may be bradycardia and decreased tone. BP remains normal

Can originate in CNS due to asphyxia or peripherally due to neuromuscular disorders
Respond to tactile stimulation Require ventilatory assistance and drugs- caffeine or theophylline

questions.text: A 15-day-old infant had conjunctivitis, which later developed into respiratory distress and pneumonia. Chest X-ray examination revealed bilateral lung infiltrates. Peripheral smear count showed 14,300/dL (N 43, L 54, E3).  Which of the following is the most likely pathogenic organism?
questions.solution:
The organism most likely to cause the mentioned infections is Chlamydia trachomatis.

Pneumonia caused by C. trachomatis can develop in 10–20% of infants born to women with active, untreated chlamydial infection. Only approximately 25% of infants with nasopharyngeal chlamydial infection develop pneumonia.

C. trachomatis pneumonia of infancy has a very characteristic presentation. It usually occurs between 1-3 months of age and is insidious, with a persistent cough, tachypnea, and absence of fever. Auscultation reveals rales; wheezing is uncommon.

The absence of fever and wheezing helps to distinguish C. trachomatis pneumonia from respiratory syncytial virus pneumonia.

A distinctive laboratory finding is the presence of peripheral eosinophilia (>400 cells/µL).
The most consistent finding on chest radiograph is hyperinflation accompanied by minimal interstitial or alveolar infiltrates.

questions.text: The radiologist calls and confirms a Bochdalek hernia in a baby born with multiple congenital anomalies. The baby had been placed under an oxygen hood in the NICU, in view of postnatal respiratory distress. On repeat evaluation, he continues to have sternal retractions and is not maintaining saturation. Which of the following would be your initial clinical intervention in this case?

choices.text: Intubate and insert a nasogastric tube
Insert a central venous pressure line

questions.solution:
Once the diagnosis of congenital diaphragmatic hernia is made or suspected, all patients are intubated. Also a nasogastric tube, connected to continuous suction, is placed in the stomach to reduce lung compression. 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect of the diaphragm. The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia (postero-lateral diaphragmatic hernia); other types include Morgagni hernia (anterior-parasternal), diaphragm eventration, and central tendon defects of the diaphragm. Malformation of the diaphragm allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity, hindering proper lung formation and expansion.

Immediate steps of management: 

Endotracheal intubation → Placement of a nasogastric tube  → Administration of fluids and inotropic agents → Administration of surfactant therapy to only preterm infants with findings suggestive of respiratory distress syndrome.Other options:

Option B: Bag and mask ventilation is to be avoided as they lead to gastric/abdominal distension and compression of the lung.

Option C: Both arterial and central venous lines are inserted; however, this is not the first line of intervention.

Option D: To support respiratory failure, the first modality to be used is conventional ventilation, and if there is no improvement, then high-frequency ventilation is used.

questions.text: A newborn delivered vaginally, at term, was diagnosed with congenital diaphragmatic hernia. The most important limiting factor for survival in this condition is ________.
questions.solution:
Pulmonary hypoplasia is a very poor prognostic factor in congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Poor prognostic indicators in CDH: 

  • The presence of liver in the thoracic cavity 
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia, pulmonary hypertension 
  • Early respiratory distress, within 24 h after birth 
  • Need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
  • Herniation to the contralateral lung (right-sided hernia)

questions.text: You are doing a quick pre-op evaluation of a 2-day-old baby shifted for emergency pediatric surgery. Parents had brought him with a history of sudden, noisy breathing. He appeared cyanotic with decreased breath sounds on the left side of the chest. Chest X-ray taken in the casualty is given below. Which of the following is not true about the underlying condition?

choices.text: Most commonly seen on the left side
Mortality is usually associated with pulmonary hypoplasia
Pulmonary dilators markedly improve the survival

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of neonatal respiratory distress, absent breath sounds in the left side of the chest, and an X-ray image showing bowel loops in the thoracic cavity is diagnostic of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). Though less commonly documented, dextrocardia is seen in association with CDH.

A diaphragmatic hernia is defined as a communication between the abdominal and thoracic cavities with or without abdominal contents in the thorax. It is mostly congenital, with a defective formation of the pleuroperitoneal membrane. Females are affected twice as often as males.

Bochdalek hernia accounts for up to 90% of the hernias seen in the newborn period, with 80-90% occurring on the left side. So, the heart will be pushed to the right side (dextroposition).

Predictors of a poor prognosis include an associated major anomaly, symptoms before completion of 24 hours since birth, severe pulmonary hypoplasia, herniation to the contralateral lung, and the need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

Nitric oxide is a selective pulmonary vasodilator. It reduces ductal shunting and pulmonary pressures, resulting in improved oxygenation.
